MEET ME, MAX EHNERT

About Me

I have always had a passion for building things. This can be seen from my hobbies and previous work experience. I enjoy taking a project from concept to finished product. When I am not in front of a computer screen, I enjoy attending automotive events.

My background was in rebuilding large-frame generators for multinational power generation companies. Prior to that I was a machinist stationed aboard the USS Emory S. Land in the Navy.

Before attending The Iron Yard Academy, I was majoring in mechanical engineering at the University of Wisconsin- Milwaukee. While attending UWM I owned and operated an automotive repair business with a focus on european cars.

I am currently employed by Emory University, helping the engineers and doctors in the Department of Biomedical Informatics. I am tasked with the development of several web application used in their research. The interfaces I am developing are designed to annotate over different waveforms to check patient heart activity and sound. I develop on both the client and server side using modern web tools and frameworks.

At Emory University, I helped the engineers and doctors in the Department of Biomedical Informatics. I was tasked with the development of several web applications used in their research. The interfaces developed are designed to annotate over different waveforms to check patient heart activity and sound. I developed on both the client and server side using modern web tools, frameworks, and cloud computing.

My Skills

I am an expert of HTML5 and CSS3 best practices. I am very experienced writing JavaScript as-well-as libraries such as jQuery and lodash. This can be seen in all of my featured applications below.

Angular is my go-to MVC of choice. I also have experience using Backbone and have several examples below utilizing both MVC frameworks. I am comfortable writing full scale applications in either frameworks.

Having built several interfaces utilizing Laravel I am experienced working in this environment. I use it with SQLite for my database. I use Laravel heavily with JavaScript on the client side.
